name: Phenobarbital
summary: Phenobarbital is a long-acting barbiturate used as an anticonvulsant and sedative-hypnotic for the treatment of seizure disorders, sedation, and, in some cases, withdrawal management.
description: Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that enhances GABA-mediated inhibitory neurotransmission by prolonging the duration of chloride channel opening at the GABA-A receptor, producing sedative, hypnotic, and anticonvulsant effects. It is one of the oldest antiepileptic drugs and is primarily used for partial and generalized tonic-clonic seizures, status epilepticus, and seizure prophylaxis. It is also used off-label for alcohol and benzodiazepine withdrawal in certain cases.

items: Status epilepticus (as an alternative or adjunct)

sections.text: Phenobarbital binds to the GABA-A receptor, prolonging the opening of chloride channels and enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission, thereby reducing neuronal excitability.

adult.Status epilepticus: 10–20 mg/kg IV at a rate ≤ 60 mg/min

sections.geriatric: Use lower initial doses; monitor for excessive sedation and respiratory depression.

sections.text: Onset: 20–60 minutes orally; 5 minutes IV. Duration: 4–10 hours (sedative effects), up to 48–96 hours (anticonvulsant effects).

sections.black_box: Risk of dependence, misuse, and withdrawal reactions; abrupt discontinuation may cause life-threatening seizures.
other: Caution in patients with hepatic impairment
May cause paradoxical excitement in children and elderly

sections.pregnancy: May cause fetal harm; use only if benefits outweigh risks.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation in the infant.
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of sedation and falls; use lowest effective dose.

sections.text: Gradual taper over several weeks to avoid withdrawal symptoms, including seizures.

items: One of the oldest and most cost-effective anticonvulsants available.
Has largely been replaced by newer agents in many high-income countries but remains widely used globally.
Useful in resource-limited settings due to low cost and broad efficacy.
